title: Before 1 January 2021, will it be announced that the fueling of the Vogtle nuclear reactor Unit 3 has begun?
preds: Vogtle Unit 3 just received their first shipment of nuclear fuel. They must still conduct Hot Functional Testing before the fuel is loaded [1]. [1] https://www.southerncompany.com/newsroom/2020/dec-2020/georgia-power-receives-first-nuclear-fuel-shipment-for-vogtle-unit-3.html

"And loading of nuclear fuel for the first reactor, a pivotal milestone, has been pushed back four months to April of 2021." https://www.ajc.com/news/progress-slips-again-at-vogtle-nuclear-plant/OK656Q6TQFHANDQW72D2ASP76E/
News: Georgia Power said ... delaying the loading of nuclear fuel for the first reactor another four months, to April 2021.
Back down 15% based on post below.

I know I'm all over the place on this... but Georgia Power made a statement that January, 2021 is their target for Hot Functional Testing [1], but it could also start as late as the end of March [2] [1] https://www.nucnet.org/news/hot-functional-testing-for-unit-3-could-begin-in-january-10-5-2020
[2] https://apnews.com/press-release/pr-newswire/business-virus-outbreak-government-business-and-finance-diseases-and-conditions-products-and-services-06ecbf42af3888cce3b3d1a5bb681ed7

Well..... they announced completion of Cold Hydro Testing [1] without announcing ahead of time that it was occurring.... or at least I missed it if they did. With only one test remaining before they would begin fueling - under the aggressive model - I'm swinging pretty aggressively towards it happening before the end of the year. [1] https://electricenergyonline.com/news.php?ID=861288&cat=;52&niveauAQ=0

I emailed the Southern Company asking when the Vogtle Unit 3 fueling is going to start.  
Their reply:  "Schedule on line date for Unit 3 is Nov 2021. And a year later for Unit 4"   I realize the online date isn't the same as the start of the fueling.  I am assuming there isn't a year lag time from the start of refueling and on line.
Dropping to 0 - no announcement of cold hydro testing in October, which is only the second to last step BEFORE fueling can even begin.....
swinging down in line with the lack of news.

If they were going to conduct cold hydro testing in the last week of September, they would have announced it last week. The fact that they have not indicates that they are not on track for the "aggressive" timeline. Its possible that they conduct  cold hydro testing in October, Hot Functional Testing in November, and conduct fuel load in December.... but not likely at this point.
With about 10 days to go in the month, no announcement so far of Cold Hydro testing. If that doesn't happen by the end of the month I'm dropping to 0.
Half-way through September and no news on Cold Hydro testing...which would need to begin this month to keep us on track for the "aggressive" timeline that would allow for fueling before Jan 1.

New analyst report: Southern Co. (SO -2.4%) slumps as Mizuho downgrades shares to Underperform from Neutral with a $48 price target, trimmed from $53, finding it unlikely the company will be able to complete the Vogtle nuclear project within the regulatory approved timeline. The current slow pace of ITAAC clearances makes it "almost impossible" to achieve Southern's site plan for Vogtle's completion, says Mizuho analyst Paul Fremont, who also sees an increasing likelihood of cost overruns for the project.

Shifting upwards, due to a combination of American neglect of the seriousness of Sars-Cov-19 (1) and the reported progress of Unit 3 (2). Georgia Power (GP) has stated that "Fuel loading of Unit 3 also is planned by year-end" (2), now before we get excited, all this says is today if the complex testing processes can be completed without any delays and with a diminished work force, fuel loading can be achieved before years end.  The aggressive schedule outline I previously linked shows a 3 month lag between start of hot functional testing and fuel loading, which makes this achievable if we believe GP's schedule, but it also relies on no additional delays in successfully testing an extremely complex system in 2020.  1. https://www.globalconstructionreview.com/news/800-covid-cases-americas-only-nuclear-construction/
2. https://www.powermag.com/georgia-power-new-vogtle-unit-still-set-for-2021-startup/
I haven't found any recent news on the fueling progress.  I am having doubts in my overconfident forecast, but leaving it for now until I can get more info and updates.

Slight drop in likelihood, but testing looks like it may be complete close to the aggressive site work plan dates outlined in (1).  If hot functional testing is wrapped shortly, there's no reason refueling cannot begin before 2021 1. https://www.powermag.com/is-vogtle-nuclear-expansion-on-schedule-ceo-sounds-confident/
Down 2% adjusting for time left. The term "begun" still has me pondering what might be just enough.

Local news not very bullish on the completion: "That timetable has slipped to November of next year for the first reactor and November 2022 for the second."
https://www.augustachronicle.com/business/20200816/plant-vogtle-opponents-seeking-faster-review-of-cost-to-customers

Adjusting based on revised "aggressive" plan that was published. There are other milestones/events that will occur between now and a possible fueling in November.... so if those events don't happen on time, or are shifted significantly to the right, then I'll drop this forecast to 0. Adding this link for my own reference later: https://seekingalpha.com/article/4362624-southern-company-2020-q2-results-earnings-call-presentation#

As @sebawi and @Markus4560 have pointed out, the earnings call from July 2020 outlines that the Aggressive Plan has the fueling now in January 2021 and they state that “even a delay of up to three months will enable the plant to be operational coming summer”. This tells me that they are already planning for fueling in early 2021. Adjusting my forecast significantly.
Down 15% to be below the consensus and to acknowledge very low tolerance for risk (or engineering details).
Dropping substantially based on more reading. Difficult to reconcile the conflicting data (most of it matter-of-fact vs factual)
Although the reactor has had the overhead tank installed, going by the picture of progress, there is still more than 6 months to go before the intial fuel load.
Down 15% following @sebawi below. What defines "fueling ... has begun?" (finally paying attention just a bit)

Thanks to @Markus4560 for the comment [1]. The Southern Company expects the fueling to start in January 2021, however, that is under the "Aggressive Site Work Plan" [2]. The initial plan- the so-called "November benchmark schedule" - expects it to start in July 2021. So even though they are saying that they currently exceed the initial plan, it seems unlikely that they outperform their "Aggressive Site Work Plan" as well.  [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1094621
[2] https://seekingalpha.com/article/4362624-southern-company-2020-q2-results-earnings-call-presentation# - Slides 6 and 7

I think I need to understand the process better, "On February 11, 2020, Southern Nuclear announced that the final concrete placement inside the Unit 3 containment vessel was completed which will allow installation of the reactor's fueling machine. As of February 2020, assembly continues on the final top most vertical feature of the overall Unit 3 reactor building, the passive containment cooling system storage tank, which will be set on top of the Shield Building Roof." Casual reading: https://www.power-eng.com/2020/07/14/crews-complete-closed-vessel-and-safety-testing-on-vogtle-nuclear-unit-3-reactor/#gref
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vogtle_Electric_Generating_Plant
Demand is down: https://www.spglobal.com/platts/en/market-insights/latest-news/electric-power/073020-pandemic-mild-weather-weaken-southern-co-power-demand-boost-nuke-costs

In yesterdays presentation of Q2 results Southern Co. reported that the fuel load is scheduled in the „aggressive“ plan for Jan 21. But it is added that a fuel load three month later would not endager in-service Nov 21. To me that is a strong sign that the fuel load will not happen at 1 Jan 21.

The fuel rods were purchased a year ago, and the final Critical tests have been conducted.  The CoVid issue is the one most likely to delay this. Georgia is locked into the contract and has to pay the price for delays, not the contractor, so while not full steam ahead, I think they have incentive to keep moving.   https://www.power-eng.com/2019/07/30/first-nuclear-fuel-order-placed-for-vogtle-expansion-project/
Delays based on Covid or some legal action protest.

They are hitting all the milestones so far even with a reduced workforce and pandemic restrictions. There is a possibility of a future further reduction in workforce and further restrictions which may impact progress
With a reduced workforce and short turnaround it is not incredibly likely they will hit their projections, even if there wasn't a pandemic ripping through Georgia.

Even with a 20% reduction in work force due to corona virus, GP is still hitting milestones. Although it is not required to hit the targeted November 2021 in service date, I believe it is likely that the targeted unit 3 fuel load test will still happen by the end of this year. After all, this is a publicly traded company, and their stock holders expect this.
Vogtle is a mighty cog in the nuke wheel. January is a bit early considering pandemic but these guys come in on time, sort of on budget, lol. Later in 21 I'm thinking.

Without Covid-19 fuel loading was expected to start in November. With a 20% reduction in workforce to accommodate social distancing and any other unforeseen issues due to the virus and large engineering projects, a two month (at least) extension on fuel loading is very likely.
Closed vessel testing is completed as of July 14th, which is a critical step before loading in fuel! Looks promising that we'll hear an announcement before Jan 1.
Closed Vessel testing was completed earlier this month. Temporary workforce reduction by 20% due to COVID-19 will have some impact, but can still expect the fueling announcement by January 1st.
Up 10% to be above consensus. Still need more time to grok this.
Covid-19 will have some delay but minor

There is much at stake to keep to the current schedule, but with the pandemic and there are too many uncertainties. Workforce levels are likely going to be impact and there is always the threat of hurricane season that can provide a wild card interruption,
History of cost overruns and delays due to Covid.
articles say that pressure tests are ok, milestone for November still holds, uranium prices are at record low, there fore it sure why not proceed with timely initial fuel load.

Things seem to be on track, even with the Georgia Power CEO testing positive for covid-19
- https://www.finanzen.net/nachricht/aktien/latest-round-of-major-tests-completed-on-vogtle-unit-3-containment-vessel-9064348
- https://www.ans.org/news/article-352/vogtle-site-makes-progress-with-critical-testing-of-new-units/ The first fuel load was scheduled for Nov 20
- https://www.ans.org/news/article-50/first-fuel-loading-at-unit-3-scheduled-for-november/ I have no clue why the crowd forecast is so low. I would baseline at around 65% for a Yes. Follow and revise.
They have already stated they don't the regulatory approvals they need.
this projects are never on time. and with the pandemic context
The program is long-delayed and over budget. All its estimates are way off and it faces a lot of opposition.

Arguments for fueling in 2020:
- closed vessel (structural integrity and integrated leak rate tests) testing completed mid July for Unit 3 (https://dailyenergyinsider.com/news/26307-vogtle-unit-3-reaches-new-milestones/)
- Bechtel took over the lead EPC duties in 2017 (https://www.power-eng.com/2020/07/14/crews-complete-closed-vessel-and-safety-testing-on-vogtle-nuclear-unit-3-reactor/) Arguments for fueling in 2021 and later:
- fueling of Unit 3 does not seem to be necessary to hits targets in the first place; Georgia Power "continues to work toward fuel load occurring in 2020; however, this milestone is not required to be achieved until later in 2021 to support the regulatory-approved in-service dates." (https://www.neimagazine.com/news/newscoronavirus-sees-resequencing-of-activities-at-vogtle-nuclear-project-7994387)
- covid crisis has already led to workforce reduced by 20% in April (https://www.powermag.com/vogtle-workforce-reduced-by-20-but-other-projects-strong-in-march/), further infections could trigger further delays

Moodys originally downgraded Southern Company due to a reshuffling of construction milestones at the end of June (COVID19 related), predicting that the structural integrity test and integrated leak rate test would be delayed. However, these two tests were completed, a major milestone towards fueling (currently projected to begin at the end of November). Additionally, the world's largest construction company (Bechtel) is now overseeing construction - and they have extensive experience in the nuclear space. November 23 is the milestone set by the company to begin fueling - information closer to this date will be most relevant.

Www.Powermag.com/vogtle-project-highly-unlikely-to-meet-deadlines/
The company says all will be well, and all will be well, and all manner of things will be well.  Everybody else says probably not.  Keeping an eye on it because the world is full of surprises, and those who cut regulatory corners are sometimes rewarded.  Just ask Boeing.

Considering that the former contractor Westinghouse went bankrupt during the building process, this limits the progress and the options of getting ahead of schedule, compared to from-the-scratch projects of this size and complexity.
Bechtel, however, as the subsequent contractor appears to be well-managed and successful, but there have been delays and cost issues in earlier projects of Bechtel, too: Boston Central Artery/Tunnel
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Dig
Cautiously optimistic, forecast likely to rise towards fall.
